Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam and Josh are bending over a fireplace. All three are bundled up in heavy coats, and Donna is wearing a winter hat.

Dialogues.Line: We're making a fire in a fireplace, what kind of supervision do you want?
FEMA? The American Red Cross?
What kind of wood is this?
[sighs] I don't know.
Josh...
It's freezing in here.
I acknowledge that it's cold.
It's like Ice Station Zebra.
It also might bother someone.
It's half past midnight!
See, here's the thing. This looks like spruce to me.
Yeah?
And spruce is a softwood, softwood burns out quickly. You know what we need for a slow burning fire?
A hardwood?
That's right.
That's interesting.
Where did you get the wood?
It was sitting in... the thing. [points across the room]
I think that is mean to be decorative...
It's wood, we're not burning Benjamin Harrison's log cabin.
You know what?
What?
We might be.
Why?
It was made out of spruce.
[to Donna] Where's C.J.?
She's over in the Roosevelt Room.
Is she doing the seating chart?
Yeah.
Jancowitz has a hearing aid that seldom works, he needs to be seated near the center. Would you tell her that?
Yeah. [beat] You're not using lighter fluid or anything are you?
No... no flammable liquids of any kind to start a fire, ever. Donna starts to leave when Sam re-enters carrying a kerosene lamp.
Found it!
What?
Kerosene.
[whips around] Josh...
Go.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J., Carol, Ed, Larry, and some other staffers are standing around a large seating chart for the leadership breakfast. They are all in heavy coats and many are holding steaming coffee, including C.J. who is wearing gloves. C.J. is walking around the board, placing and pointing to stands, which hold handwritten cards.

Dialogues.Line: Speaker [places stand], House Majority [places stand], House Minority, Senate Majority, Senate Minority, Whip, Whip, Deputy, Deputy.
Right.
Yes.
Then...
What?
The committee chairs.
Yes.
Ways and Means goes here.
Finance goes here, House Appropriations goes here.
Senate Appropriations here, House Budget...
Senate Budget
Excellent.
Which brings us to...
White House staff.
That's right. So, we've got the Chief of Staff.
Next to him will be the Deputy Chief of Staff. On the other side of Leo will be the Congressional Liaison, and the Political Liaison.
Next to them will be the Communications Director and the Deputy Communications Director.
What about staff aides?
The aides will stand around the wall.
So we're done?
We're set.
Yes.
[enters] C.J.?
Don't give me a thing.
Josh says Jancowitz has to sit closer to the center.
Why?
He doesn't hear well.
He can't sit closer to the center!
His hearing aid malfunctions.
Who cares? [beat] It's a breakfast to trumpet a new spirit of bi-partisanship cooperation and understanding in a new year, no ones going to be listening to each other anyways!
I'm just a messenger but I think he's saying we don't snub Jancowitz...
Because of the thing...
Yeah.
All right, we're gonna have to move somebody. Would you ask him if it's better to dis the House Whip or the Senate Whip?
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh and Sam are still working in front of the fireplace.

Dialogues.Line: You want to stand them in a tripod right?
Yeah, standing 3 sticks on an end and slanting them to a common center.
Isn't that a tripod?
Yeah, but...
You just thought you'd say more words.
Yeah.
[enters] Josh...
Hang on. [to Sam] You know what we need?
Dried leaves.
We need dried leaves.
To move Jancowitz, we've got to move either the House or Senate Whip. JOSH and SAM House.
Why?
'Cause life is tough in the big cruel world, and if he doesn't like it, he can kiss me!
So, the spirit of bi-partisanship begins!
Yeah.
Could you possible get us some dried leaves?
Yeah, I'll just run out to the forest and be right back. [leaves]
You know what?
You think she was being sarcastic?
Yeah, I don't think she's getting the leaves.
You know what we could use?
Newspaper?
See, this is what I'm talking about, this is teamwork!
It really is!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: [enters] House.
House?
Yes.
So, we'll move the House Whip to the left of Sam and move Jancowitz across from Leo and we're all set right?
Yeah.
Larry, Ed we're set? [beat] Either one of you?
Yeah.
Yes.
Thank you, you see, you guys thought it was going to take a long time and it only ended up taking 7 and a half hours.
[enters] Somebody working on the heat?
Seating arrangement is set.
That took some time.
It was hard.
You got to find a magic marker.
Toby, when people are sitting with the President, there's excruciating protocol involved.
Uh-oh.
What?!?
Missed one...
Who?
Take a look. C.J. and the others are bent over the table looking.
I'm looking...
It'll happen.
Okay, guys. You know what we did? We forgot the President.
[holding up card holder off to side of the board] There it is!
[enters] Does anybody smell smoke?
Oh God! [leaves quickly]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh and Sam are backing away in a cloud of smoke. Josh coughs.

Dialogues.Line: I think this might be because the wood is wet.
Well, the fire ought to dry it pretty quick shouldn't it?
You'd think.
[rushes in] What'd you do?!
It's going pretty good now.
There's smoke in the hallways! Toby and C.J. enter.
What the hell is going on?
The wood's drying out.
Are you burning a dining room table?!
Spruce is a slow drying wood.
Do you have any idea whet you're talking about?
No.
Hang on. [reads a small plaque on the wall next to the fireplace]
Are those instructions?
It says this fireplace was a favor to President Andrew Johnson and he would sip whiskey from a charcoal keg while reading by its light.
That doesn't help.
The flue's been welded shut since 1896.
Well that's probably it then.
[enters] What are you doing?!
Somebody started a fire in this fireplace, Charlie.
If the smoke alarms go off, they're going to make me wake up the President!
The President's a thousand yards over and two flights up.
It's Secret Service procedure.
Well, let's get a fire extinguisher and put it out before the smoke alar... Smoke alarms begin to blare. All the staffers look at each other, and C.J. covers her ears.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE THE PRESIDENTIAL BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The door flies open to reveal a very unhappy Bartlet.

Dialogues.Line: What?!
Mr. President, you know how you told me not to wake you up unless the building was on fire?

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: These are the rules.
They're the guidelines.
The meeting will last 90 minutes.
Yes.
And the rules.
The guidelines.
We can't talk about the Patient's Bill of Rights?
We can talk about the Patient's Bill of Rights. We just can't talk about dropping the provision that would allow for litigation.
Why not?
Because that's not what the breakfast is for.
What's it for?
Symbolize the spirit of cooperation as the new session begins and to eat pancakes.
So with regard to the Patient's Bill of Rights we'll just be debating the things we agree on?
Yeah.
And raising the minimum wage?
We won't be talking about that at all.
No, we shouldn't because there's a chance it could lead to something.
We can't talk about the patient's bill of rights?
We can talk about it. We just can't talk about dropping the no litigation clause.
Leo, what's the point of having rights if you can't sue for them in court?
That's a fine argument.
We won't be making it.
Not at this breakfast.
And the minimum wage?
Not so much.
I see won't be talking about the 993 tax cut.
We won't be. But we've agreed to call it tax relief instead of a tax cut.
We're calling it tax relief.
Yeah.
But we won't be talking about it.
No.
Leo, the Patient's Bill of Rights.
Which we'll be referring to as the Comprehensive Access and Responsibility Act.
What's the Comprehensive Access and Responsibility Act?
It's the Patient's Bill of Rights, but the CARA was introduced in 1999. It's fundamentally the same thing and the Republicans have agreed to discuss changing the name back.
In exchange for calling tax breaks tax relief.
Or income enhancement.
I'm in a musical.
Getting it renamed for the old bill is a hell of a concession.
Leo, I'm gonna check in with you for a second, OK?
Sure.
Sick people...
Yeah.
Not getting proper medical care...
Right.
Because they can't afford it...
Yes.
Probably don't care that we've agreed to change the name of the bill.
We've agreed to discuss changing the name of the bill. Bartlet and Charlie enter THE OVAL OFFICE. Sam, Leo, Josh, and Toby are lined up at the desk.
What's after that?
Security briefing.
After that?
Agriculture.
Who was the idiot who set off the smoke detector?
Well it sounds a lot like you are talking about Sam, Mr. President.
What, were you inconvenienced, Sir?
They had me on the Truman balcony for 6 minutes in my underwear.
Was it cold?
In January? No. Why do you ask?
Mr. President I'd like to talk about those rules in that memo you're reading.
It's a breakfast. Toby, it's a pancake breakfast. There's nothing in that memo that's important.
We're having Vermont maple syrup?
Mr. President, if you read item 4 you'll see that time at this breakfast will be spent discussing calling the Patient's Bill of Rights the Comprehensive Access and Responsibility Act.
I don't give a damn if they call it the Monroe doctrine. What the hell are we doing serving Vermont maple syrup?
On the minimum wage, if we all turn our attention to item 5 of the Rules of Bipartisan Breakfast.
They're guidelines. You keep calling them rules.
Margaret, what does it say at the top of the memo?
Rules for Bipartisan Breakfast.
[to Margaret] I keep meaning to fire you.
Yeah.
New Hampshire syrup is what we serve in this White House.
Sir.
It's a breakfast. We eat. We pose for pictures. You do a post-game conference. Everybody gets the hell out of here and I don't have to be so Officer Crupky.
Anything else?
An ONB efficiency expert has said we could free up much need office space by moving the Press Room across the street.
What else? No response.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you. Everyone leaves. Leo motions for Josh to enter his OFFICE.
Josh.
Yeah.
You feeling all right?
Yeah.
You're sure?
Yeah.
You don't mind me asking?
Nah.
Because I'm gonna ask you once a day, okay?
Okay, but you just asked me four times in the last ten seconds.
I want you to go to Ben and Sally's for dinner tonight.
Are you going?
No.
Was I invited?
No.
Are Ben and Sally asking for me?
No, they'd rather you didn't come, but they'll do me a favor and I need you to do me one too.
What's at Ben and Sally's?
Karen Cahill.
And what stupid-ass Irish thing did you say to Karen Cahill that you now need me to apologize at Ben and Sally 's like a little girl? Leo glares at Josh rather sternly.
Let me tell you what was surprising about that moment just then. I said that only 12 hours after you were very cool about my almost accidentally setting the building on fire.
I made a joke about her shoes.
I'm sorry?
I made a remark about her shoes.
You're the second most powerful man in the country...
And she relates a column for the New York Times and who knows what kind of special relationship women have with their shoes!
What could you possibly have said...?
It doesn't matter. It was perfectly benign to anyone who doesn't take shoes that seriously. Just tell her that I love her and that I'm sorry and I'll take her shoe shopping.
Why don't you tell her?
If someone else tells her it seems like I was thoughtful enough to mention it. If I tell her it just makes me seem feminine.
You don't think the shoe shopping's gonna take care of that?
Let's call the insurance company and see how much water damage was done in the mural room.
You don't need to wave a stick, Leo. I am totally there for you.
Thank you.
Can I get Sam to do it?
Fine.
Anything else?
Nope.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Carol are meeting with ANN STARK and three of her staffers.

Dialogues.Line: This isn't about what they say after the meeting so let's decide what they're gonna say.
It'll be simple enough.
Like what?
We appreciate the President's invitation and welcome him to the cause of bipartisanship.
[while eating breakfast] And I'll end the press conference.
You're gonna walk him into the cause of bipartisanship?
What's the problem?
I think C.J.'s objecting to the implication that we got there first.
Yes.
How about 'we all agree on a need for renewed spirit of bipartisanship.'
The meeting was positive.
Yes.
Friendly, frank, and productive
Yes.
And we're certain our goals can be met under the President's leadership.
No way.
What's the problem?
I think what my aide is objecting to is the implication it's the President's leadership under which our goals will be met.
Meeting was positive, friendly, frank and productive.
With a spicy bouquet that suggests a fine Merlot. Her staffers smile.

[looking over her notes] The President will be at the northwest entrance. Assuming we're done at 1030, the Majority Leader will speak and take questions, the Minority Leader, then C.J. will answer questions 20 minutes later in the Briefing Room.
If all goes well we should...
[cuts her off] I got to stop you. Why in the Briefing Room?
That's where I brief.
The Majority Leader is briefing first and outside. You're doing it last in back of a podium and in front of a blue curtain with a big picture of the White House.
And the Majority Leader'll be doing it in front of the actual White House.
No, he'll be doing it on the Capitol steps.
Traditionally, these kinds of things are done in front of the White House.
Traditionally, the person in my job has cared what's traditional.
The President's not gonna want to end a bipartisan breakfast with the Republicans speaking from one place and the Democrats...
And the Majority Leader's not gonna stand at a cardboard podium in your front yard while you stand in White House Press briefing room and with good reason.
Which is?
I don't think they're on equal footing.
My boss and your boss?
Yes.
I don't think they are either.
And, the Majority Leader is gonna brief outside. If the majority leader wants to skip breakfast there'll be more pancakes for the rest of us. My press room can write about why.
[shrugs] Well, you can't blame a girl for trying. Toby enters.
You need me?
[points to Ann] Can I borrow her for a moment?
We'll wait. Toby and Ann step out to the HALLWAY.
These rules are crap.
The guidelines. We're working with C.J. right now.
I could care less who says what in what order. I'm talking about what we say when we sit down.
You've got concerns.
Yes, I do.
Name one.
The president prefers maple syrup from New Hampshire. [Ann laughs.] I'm not kidding.
Then we'd better meet on this.
Breakfast tomorrow.
What should I wear?
I don't give a damn. [opens the door for her]
I've heard different. Ann returns to her meeting in THE ROOSEVELT ROOM.
945. So we got that straight. Where were we?
You were giving me and my staff an ultimatum.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna walks in.

Dialogues.Line: Sam.
Did you know there's a swimming pool underneath the press Briefing Room?
I didn't.

There's a swimming pool underneath there. And I'll tell you what else. According to the OMB efficiency auditor, there are more people working in the West Wing of the White House than in any point in history.
You wanna free up office space by kicking out the press corps.
Yeah.
And putting in a swimming pool...
I realize that there are some flaws in my logic.
Yeah. Leo needs a favor.
What?
He needs you to go to dinner at Ben and Sally's and apologize to Karen Cahill for making fun of her shoes.
I didn't make fun of her shoes.
He did.
I don't have any problem with her shoes.
Leo did.
What was his problem with her shoes?
Doesn't matter. Just do what you usually do.
Here's the thing. Sam stands up nervously and walks out of his office. Donna follows.
What?
I don't do well with Karen.
Why?
I get nervous.
What happens?
I become unimpressive.
In what way?
In many ways.
You don't fall down, do you?
Once.
You'll be fine.
You think?
You'll be impressive.
I never have been before, but that's no reason to think I'm not gonna do it.
Right.
You know why?
Doesn't really matter.
Perseverance. You get right back on the horse. I'm gonna sit there and she's gonna go home saying, "that Sam Seaborn's impressive." I'm gonna say nice things about her.
Reach for the stars, Sam!
I will!
Good. They part.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby enters.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah.
I'm gonna have breakfast with Ann Stark tomorrow.
Leave it alone.
I think we should be able to discuss the minimum wage and-
Toby. It's a brand new year.
Let's not faf around!
It's breakfast.

I know. It's breakfast. We're not gonna come up with solutions in 90 minutes. But we have the principles in a room and no cameras. The-[utters a small laugh] the leaders of the land. And not to talk about how we're gonna approach the minimum wage, the Patient's Bill of Rights, Tax relief, and education in the legislative session that's about to begin is a criminally negligent and cowardly refusal to do... what we were all sent her to do. [beat] This is what my ex-wife and I did for years. We had these rules. We could talk about anything but why we couldn't live with each other. I could've been two years younger right now.

There was a freshman democrat who came to Congress 50 years ago. He turned to a senior Democrat and said, "Where are the Republicans? I want to meet the enemy. The senior Democrat said, "The Republicans aren't the enemy. They're the opposition. The Senate is the enemy." Those days are over. Toby, in this climate...
This climate is exactly what real bipartisan debate should look like.
This woman's had this job two weeks. I don't like dealing with people who are trying to impress me.
I know her a little.
Have breakfast with her.
Thank you.
Toby.
Yeah.
Jenny and I wouldn't talk about it either. You know why?
Why?
Because we loved each other and it was awful and we knew it was never gonna change. Ever. Toby leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: I want them to talk about the minimum wage and I want them to talk about the Patient's Bill of Rights.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE MESS - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby and Ann Stark are having breakfast.

Dialogues.Line: I believe you might be talking about the Comprehensive Access and Responsibility Act there, Toby.
Yeah, well...
[pulls out a bag] I brought you a present.
What is it?
Guess.
Really?
Sure.
Why?
I would think it'd be fun.
You don't think it'd be a colossal waste of time?
You've lost your sense of humor.
It's a bottle of New Hampshire maple syrup.

It's a CAN of New Hampshire maple syrup [unwraps the can with a red bow on it] and you just ruined what I think could have been a nice moment. Ann slides over the can, and Toby fingers it on the table.
Ann.
You know, tax breaks are tax relief now and we're changing South Carolina to Italy.
The minimum wage.
You cannot muster up the behavior to say thank you?
For the syrup?
Yeah.
Thank you.
[smiles] You're welcome!
And congratulations.
Thank you.
You are now the Chief of Staff to the most powerful Republican in the country. Obviously, a great deal of confidence has been placed into you...
Where's my present?
For being promoted?
Yeah.
[clapping his pockets] Uh... I don't have one. A waiter approaches their table.
Then give me my syrup back. [takes the syrup back]
Are you ready to order?
He's going to need syrup; I have syrup here but he doesn't have any.
Scrambled eggs, wheat toast and coffee, please.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is reflected in the glass in front of Carol.

Dialogues.Line: Carol, did the President say that the stats were even more staggering right here, in Washington, D.C.? Carol walks inside.
Yeah.
Would you remind me to clarify that?
Why?
He was in Louisville, Kentucky, when he said it. Carol nods and exits the office. Sam walks in.
Hey!
Hey.
You got my note?
About moving the Press Room to the OEOB...
Yeah.
[in a sweetly patronizing tone] I did. She walks past him outside her office. Sam follows.
And?
Don't let anyone ever know that you wrote it and don't ever mention it again under any circumstances!
Moving the Press Room?
See what you did?
You mentioned it.
Look, if...
You did it again.
No, I didn't.
You were about to.
Just to OEOB, just across the street.
We're not getting a swimming pool, Sam.

I know we're not getting a swimming pool, but we can get the much-needed office space. And we can put a little physical distance between the press and the President. And we can put them just across the street in a state-of-the-art facility.
[constantly in motion, while Sam follows] By 'state-of-the-art,' you mean...
A room with... electricity.
The press doesn't want physical distance from the President, and the American people would prefer it the President didn't have physical distance from the press!
C.J.!
We can't exile the press!
The room I'm talking about is one hundred yards from where we're standing!
It sends a signal we're trying to hide things from them.
We are trying to hide things from them. But I don't think we're going to be any better at it if they're across the street.
[stops, very articulately] NO!
I'll get some more information for you.
[walking away from him] I don't need more information.
So that you can ruminate on it.
I don't need to ruminate!
Excellent! Donna walks by him.
Josh!
How did it go?
Hang on a second. Sam follows Josh into JOSH'S OFFICE.
[walking into his office with coffee] What do you need?
Did the monthly DNC go out yet?
It's going out now.
Is there time to tack on a question?
Yeah. Donna, get me the polling center at Global Strategies Group!
Yep.
What's the question?
C.J. thinks if we move the press out of the West Wing, the American people will object.
She's crazy.
So I want to show her numbers.
Mike at Global Strategies.

[picks up the phone] I want to tack on a question, okay? "Would you object?.." "Would you have?.." "Yes or no would you have an objection if..." [to Sam, closing the mouthpiece] What should the question be?
"If the White House would move the Press Corps to Trenton, New Jersey, would you give a flying...?"
Okay. [into the phone] "Would you object to the White House moving the Press Room out of the West Wing and into a facility across the street?" Read it back. Donna comes and stands at the threshold.
[to Sam] How'd it go?
It went great. [to Josh] I had to talk to Karen Cahill last night.
Did you fall down at all?

I did not. In fact, we were talking about the stability of former Soviet Republics and their fear of Islamic extremism and I have to say that I made some very scholarly points regarding the remains of nuclear weapons in Kyrgyzstan, and I have to believe...
[behind him, reading a paper at his desk] Kazakhstan.
[turning to him] Hmmm?
The nuclear weapons are in Kazakhstan.
I said Kyrgyzstan?
Yeah.
Yeah, well, Kyrgyzstan has no nuclear weapons.
No.
Kazakhstan is a country four times the size of Texas and has a sizable number of former Russian missile silos.
Yeah.
Kyrgyzstan is on the side of a hill near China and has mostly nomads and sheep.
I'm sure you got it right last night.
Yes. I'm sure. Okay. [leaves as in complete panic]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby and Ann are walking back to TOBY'S OFFICE.

Dialogues.Line: It's a photo-op, Toby. Let them talk about the Redskins and their kids.
And why not talk about the minimum wage?
Because, you'll say you want it raised two dollars in 50-cent increments over two years and we'll say three years.
Ann, do you know what a full-time worker, employed at five dollars and fifteen cents an hour, makes in a year?
Ten thousand seven hundred and twelve dollars.
Which is 26 hundred dollars below the poverty line. Why have a minimum wage?
Now you're talking!
Ann, I was just...
Do you really think raising the minimum wage is gonna put a dent in the poverty rate?
I'm saying it could at least keep up with inflation! In the last thirty years, the purchasing power of the minimum wage has gone down 30%, while you know how much the stock market has gone up?

A hundred and fifteen percent. Toby, small businesses will fold or produce less because they can't afford to pay a federally mandated wage! The unemployed will, in turn, face higher prices while receiving no wage.
Fine, so let's talk about it at breakfast!
No!
Why?
Because, 20 senators will call me and say, 'What the hell are you doing, starting the ball rolling without us?'

No, they will call and say, 'What the hell are you doing, rolling the ball at all?' You're gonna sandbag the thing in committee. You've shown us your whole hand. You're playing a game and not that well.
I just got here!
Your predecessor didn't play it well.
Maybe that's why they gave me her job.
Ann, we're not going to get screwed around on the wage hike.
No?
We have the votes and you know it.
Well, having the votes doesn't matter that much if the leader decides there isn't going to be a vote.
There is going to be a vote, straight up or down, and if there isn't, we'll offer the wage hike as an amendment on everything that moves!
Say that again?
You heard me the first time.
Do you not remember that I am the same person who bought you a can of syrup?
[smiles] Ann...
Toby, what have I done to make you think I'm scared of you? [beat] The Patient's Bill of Rights.
We can talk about it?
We can spend fifteen minutes on dropping the litigation field.
In exchange for what?
Some flowers wouldn't be out of line.
In exchange for what?
The spirit of bipartisanship?
In. Exchange. For what?
I want the press conference at the Hill. Our guys are tired of looking like the President's stupid cousin.
That's all?
Yeah.
You want the press conference at the Hill?
Yeah.
Done.
C.J. Cregg says no.
C.J. works for me.
[laughs, stands up as Toby walks her out] Thank you for breakfast.
You're welcome. Ann leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is reading in a chair as Charlie walks in. Bartlet, not seeing him, yells.

Dialogues.Line: Charlie!
[quietly] Yes, sir.
Who's the next meeting?
Kim Woo of Singapore. You want the cheat sheet?

I don't need a cheat sheet. [takes his glasses off] Kim Woo, he won a bronze medial for fencing, he's a Buddhist, and he enjoys European History. You see Charles's even thought it's a handshake, I'm able to make him feel like a friend and that's a little thing they call 'people skills.'
Kim Woo's a woman, sir.
The man's an Olympic athlete, Charlie. I wouldn't say that to his face.
Sir?
What else?
[gives Bartlet a file] Sam wanted me to show you some remarks he jotted down for your toast at the breakfast tomorrow.
on glasses, reads] Ladies and Gentleman. [beat] That's funny. [pause, while he reads] Yeah, that's funny. [laughs, to Charlie] She's a woman?
Yes.
Did you mark that down?
Yes, sir.

[reads the speech] "We spend so much time demonizing the other side, treating our opponents as if they were strangers with which we share nothing in common that we've lost sight perhaps of the greater truths." [beat, to Charlie] Did you know it's bad luck to toast with water?
I didn't.
Yeah, you don't want to make a toast with water.
Should we go, sir? [about to leave]
From Greek mythology, I'm almost sure. You lose your spirit. [reads again]
To what?
[continues reading] Hmm?
To what do you loose your spirit?
That's a great question, Charlie, and I could tell you, but I think it's better if you look it up on your own.
I'll hit the library as soon as I get off work tonight at 1:00 AM. [gathers his coat]

[reads] "That we lost sight of the greater truths. There's a lot more that unites Americans than divides them." That's good. "There's a lot more that unites Americans than divides them." [stands up] Remind me to tell Sam that's good.
Yes, sir.
And remind me not to make a toast with water.
[helping him put his jacket on] Yes, sir.
Ah. Let's go... As they leave, Bartlet puts on his jacket.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna is at her desk. Sam stands in the doorway behind her.

Dialogues.Line: I said the wrong one.
Maybe not.
I'm fairly certain.
You had a 50/50 chance.
It was Karen Cahill. There was a 99 of a 100 chance of saying the right one. I said the wrong one.
[walking over to a filing cabinet] Why do you guys get worked into a lather over Karen Cahill?
[following her] She's a very influential woman.
You're a very influential man.
She's a columnist, she gets the last word.
You talk to lots of columnists.
She has some kind of special powers.
You think?
Yeah.
Well, maybe you didn't get it wrong.
I got it wrong.
No, maybe there really are remaining nuclear weapons in Kyrgizstan.
There are barely pots and pans in Kyrgizstan.
You think the New York Times is going to make fun of you?
I do.
Well you're kind of used to that by now, right? She begins walking down the hallway.
Yeah. [again following her] Here's what we're gonna do.
We're gonna do something?
You're gonna talk to her.
[stopping] I don't even know her.
You've met.
Ohhuh we've been introduced.
And you said you felt the two of you made a connection.
That's true. [starts walking again]
Here's what you're gonna do.
[placing files on a desk] I connect with people, Sam.
Yes.
I'm a people person.
That's great. You're going to the Southstreet Exhibit tonight.
How did you know?
You told me. She's going too.
How do you know?
She told me.
So there's quite a bit of reconnaissance that went into this thing.

Yes. Here's what you're gonna do. You're gonna go up to her 'Hi I'm Donna Moss, I don't know if you remember me, I'm Josh Lyman's assistant.' You just had to come up to her cause you knew she'd get a kick out of this. Sam Seaborn's being so cute, he was talking to you and he thinks he may have said Kyrgizstan when he obviously meant Kazakhstan.
Sam Seaborn's being so cute?
It 'd kill you?
No.
Thank you.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is leaning over her table when Toby knocks on the open door.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah?
Yeah. I just had breakfast with Ann Stark.
Minimum wage?
No.
It's for the best. [moves to her desk]
Why?
Cause they'll be a fight.
Yes.
Toby...
There should be a fight. We disagree on something important and immediate.
Which means there should be a compromise.
Which isn't going to happen by posing for a picture.
It isn't gonna happen eating pancakes either, Toby, so let 'em tell dirty jokes for 90 minutes, shake hands, and start the year.
Not when it's the taxpayers' pancakes.
The taxpayers will be happy to know that the Democrats are trying to tighten heir belts where they can.
They're willing to put a provision of the patients' bill up for discussion.
Well, that's a little something you can all disagree on.
Fifteen minutes.
You can do a lot of disagreeing in fifteen minutes.
In exchange she wants the press conference on the hill.
Now she wants the whole thing on the hill?!
Yeah, listen-
I said 'no' yesterday to the split conference what makes her think...
Because I'm asking you to.
What!?
That's what they get in exchange.
Are you kidding me?!
Look...
Toby, are you kidding me?!
Who cares whether...?
First of all, I don't even know where to start...
But first of all, if they say anything that needs a response I need twenty minutes with staff. I can't stand around there and huddle in front of the White House and Congressional Press Corps.
There's not gonna be a surprise, you've already decided what you're gonna say, which is not much of anything at all!

[steps in front of him] We don't speak for the President on the steps of the capital, we don't need to be offered their microphone it makes us look like less than what we are, in fact, it makes us look small!
We're calling tax breaks tax reliefs, refusing to discuss raising the salary of those living in poverty, arguing the seating arrangement and you think that's going to make us look small?
Toby.
We're talking about the no litigation clause for fifteen minutes. I don't care if the damn press conference is outside the rotary club. She's clearly not happy, as she turns back to her desk.
It shouldn't be me then.
Fine.
It should be the deputy.
I'll tell Ann it's not going to be you.

I think this is a bad idea. I think the first visual we get is that Congress is the seat of power and the President is irrelevant. Not only that, but you just took my legs out from under me with Ann! Are you ordering me to move it to the hill?
I don't like doing that.
You're gonna have to.
[beat] Do it.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. OUTSIDE CAPITOL HILL - DAY
Scenes.Description: This next part cuts back and forth between Toby's office, C.J.'s office, in front of the Capitol Building, and the room where Ann is watching the press conference. The speakers voices at the press conference fade in and out. Cuts will be marked by ~. Reporters and Congressman getting ready for the press conference.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Steve, the reporter, is waiting for C.J., as she walks in.

Dialogues.Line: It's about to start.
Hey Steve, you should be up on the hill.
I'm gonna watch it on TV. I wanted to ask you, are you guys thinking about moving the press room across he street?
No.
I heard you were discussing it.
From who?
Chris.
It's starting.
She seemed pretty sure you were discussing it.
Why?
She got called by a pollster who asked her how she felt...
She got called by a pollster.
Yeah.
She herself got called.
Anyway.
It's starting.
Let me get into it.
Thanks. He leaves, as Carol comes in. A Congressman is speaking through the television.

Good morning. We're joined to day by Congressman Dade, Congressman Shallot, Senator Hammond and Senator Ford. Unfortunately the Senate Majority Leader has a sore throat and is unable to join us here, he's gone back to his office. We've just concluded a very frank and productive...
When did he get a sore throat?
I-I don't...
She took the Majority Leader off the board.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. OUTSIDE CAPITOL HILL - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: ...we all feel is an important moment of bipartisanship as we face the coming legislative session. We thought we'd answer some questions for a few moments this morning. Yes?
Was the Patients Bill of Rights discussed?
The Comprehensive Access and Responsibility Act, yes it was discussed.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: She took him off the board. A pause. C.J. appears to be thinking out loud.
Was it a balance thing? No, she didn't want balance she wanted power.
Maybe...
Why would she take her boss off the board?
We discussed the litigation clause but again I don't want to get into the specifics of... Yes?
We're about to get hit.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. OUTSIDE CAPITOL HILL - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: What about minimum wage hike?
The wage hike was not discussed.
Well, are you considering a two-dollar increase over two years?
Well, we want the same thing over three years, certainly...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ANN STARK'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Ann watches the conference from a monitor.

Dialogues.Line: C'mon, Simon.
Greg?
Call on Simon.
Is it fair to say it's the Majority Leader whose holding this up and not the majority?
Well I don't think it's fair to say either. Yeah, in the back, Simon?

Congressman, I'm quoting a Senior White House Aid who says they have the votes. The aid said that unless they get a straight vote up or down from the leader, and this is the quote, we're gonna attach it as an amendment on everything that moves. Ann smiles, like a coach whose player just hit a home run.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby is starting to pay more attention, and he looks worried.

Dialogues.Line: Could you say that again please?
The Senior Aide-
Listen, I don't want to comment on this

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. is watching the television intently.

Dialogues.Line: I think I'd like to get back to the breakfast meeting.
Excuse me, but uh, my friend from Michigan is far too polite to comment on this. I am not burned with any such sense of etiquette.
Congressman...

This is disgraceful. I think the record should show that a spit ball contest was begun behind our back through the press and before the 107th Congress was even gaveled into session. C.J.'s phone rings.
Want some quotes? Open your notepads.
It's Toby.
It's sadly not atypical of this White House... ~
I'm the Senior Aide.
No kidding. [to Carol] Get me Henry.
We came her in an honest effort to find common ground...
[holding the cell] Henry.
I've got Henry. What do you want?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby is silent.

Dialogues.Line: ...in this legislative session. If the White House insists on saying one thing to our face and another...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ANN STARK'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Ann is satisfied with the result.

Dialogues.Line: ...to us through the media. If the White House insists on ambushing us with ultimatums in the press...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: What do you want me to do, Toby?
[pause] Don't let him take the podium. You'll take questions in the briefing room in 20 minutes. C.J. hangs up, and speaks through the cell phone.
Henry, get home.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby slams the phone down. He's been played and he's not happy.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. OUTSIDE LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby, C.J., Sam, and Josh are waiting outside Leo's office. No one wants to speak. Leo enters and conversation moves into LEO'S OFFICE.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, what the hell happened?
That was me. [sighs] I gave Ann Stark the quote and she fed it to a reporter.
Why'd you give her the quote?
It wasn't a quote when I gave it to her.
What the hell was it?
I was letting her know we have the votes...
She knows we have the votes.
I wasn't...
She was just promoted to Chief of Staff of the Senate Majority Leader. You don't think she knows we have the votes?
[sighing] I misunderstood my relationship with Ann Stark.
Yes, you did. And now it looks like we went to the press and went for his knees.
Excuse me but Toby's not the one who gave it to the press!
You think the Majority Leader's going to believe that?
No.

It was a breakfast. It was a damn photo opportunity. The year is one week old. The legislative session hasn't begun and we can't put a forkful of waffles in our mouth without coughing up the ball. You got beat.
Yes.
I have press in ten minutes...
Figure it out. Tell me what you're going to do. They all exit and begin walking down the HALLWAY.
We can take the high road and say we don't want it to disintegrate into a war of words.
We don't want to disrupt the fragile peace...
The fragile peace has been disrupted. We've been accused of ambushing the Majority Leader in the press.
Also Labour's going to want to know if we stand by the minimum wage.
Why don't we pass it off to Labour? Have the Labour Secretary make a statement "We support the two dollar minimum wage."
Yeah, let's emphasize the close we are on this.
"We support the minimum wage hike over two years. The Republicans want it over three years. We're close to an agreement..."

Sounds like we're close to agreeing on 30 months which we're not, and no one's going to want to cover a statement from the Labour Secretary which is good, 'cause if they did it'd look like we're ducking.
No, I don't think...
She's right. We can't be passive and the high road doesn't go where we need it to. [All sigh.] Be cool, be funny, smack them down hard.
The Majority Leader is tragically out of touch with the needs of real people.
And why wasn't he at the podium? A sore throat? We know how tough that can be. Thank goodness he had health insurance.
There it is!
That's the sound bite.
And that's the new story.
Toby?
Do it.
Carol, I need voting stats on health care. [walks off]
Five minutes!
How's this for a phrase "You can lay down in front of the train or you can get on board?"
That's a really bad phrase.
Is it better if it's "You can get on board the train or you can lay down in front of it?"
No it's really bad either way. Donna walks in from the bullpen.
Josh, this was delivered by messenger.
What is it? Donna lifts the yellow envelope to her eyes.
It's... wait... wait... no. Damn, my x-ray vision is failing me today.
Give me that. Josh wanders off. Sam and Donna move into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
How'd it go?
Last night?
Did you talk to her?
Yes, I did and I explained you might have said "Kyrgyzstan" when of course you meant "Kazakhstan."
Did you say it was cute the way I worried about it?
I did.
Did it turn out I got it wrong?
She said she wasn't really listening while you were talking.
Okay...
I, on the other hand, had a most stimulating conversation with her. It was pithy, it was erudite, and most importantly it required no next day follow up explanation.
Donna? Josh wanders back in.
What was in the envelope?
Your underwear. Donna's face falls.
What?

I'm holding... your underwear... in my hand... right now. And the way I know it's your underwear is that your name sewn in the back, which is obviously something we'll spend some time talking about at a later date.
How did you get my underwear?
Donna, did you by any chance where the same pair of pants two days in a row this week?
No.
Donna?
[reluctantly] Yes.
Okay, when you get dressed on day two did you check the pant leg for the previous day's underwear?
I don't need to check the pant leg for...
Donna.
[sighs] They fell out of my pants?
It would appear that way.
Where?
The South Street exhibit.
Where?
On the floor in front of Karen Cahill.
Please tell me she's not the one...
She sent a note. Donna gasps.
[walks by] Fred and Ethel, would you follow me please?
She's talking about us. Josh tosses Donna her underwear and exits with Sam. She stuffs them in a desk drawer.
Did a question get tacked on to the monthly DNC tracking poll about moving the press room?
Yes, it did. Because I at least wanted to shoot down the argument that the public...
The public gets their news from the press, and the press gets their news...
It's a private poll. The press doesn't have access to it.
So they don't know what questions we're asking?
Yeah.
Are you sure?
The only way they'd know what questions were being asked is if they were actually called by one of the pollsters and... Oh my god!
Yes.
A reporter got called by one of the pollsters?
Yes, indeed.
Wow. What are the chances of that?
The chances of that are astronomical.
Guys...
We can calculate it. They sample 800 respondents...
Would the two of you stop being amazed by the mathematics!
All right, I'd pass it off. Just say some poor schnook in the management office got the idea and wanted to kick it around.
Sam.
It's going to be me, right?
Yeah.
Ok.
You ready?
Yeah.
You had a lot of opportunities today to say 'I told you so' and score some points with Leo. You're a class act.
Why were you holding women's underwear before?
Never really needed a reason. Eat 'em up. C.J. enters THE BRIEFING ROOM.
C.J.! C.J.! C.J.!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. SHOT OF THE CAPITOL BUILDING - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: White House Press Secretary C.J. Cregg characterized the Republican response as bizarre...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ANN STARK'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Ann is watching C.J. on TV.

Dialogues.Line: There was no intent to 'ambush' the Republican Party with an issue that's been on the table for over a year.
Ann Stark, recently installed Chief of Staff in the Majority Leader's office, said that she was surprised by the White House's information... Knocking on the door and Toby enters.
And shocked. Shocked, I say, to discover that there is gambling going on in this establishment.
Maybe if you'd gotten me a gift of some kind...
You think this is funny?
You used to have a sense of humor, Toby. Toby grunts.
Nah, you never used to have a sense of humor, Toby.
Ann...
I think you're going to have to start getting next to the idea that your party isn't in the majority.
My party's in the White House.
A building with which the Constitution does not endow sovereign power.
You think I'm going to sit around while you reduce the President to Prime Minister?
Stand or sit, we're in the majority and things are going to have to look it. And by the way, don't ever walk into my office without an appointment!
You think this could wait until an election year?
When is it not an election year?
Because ten years ago we used to be able to sit down, we'd order a couple of bourbons, we'd talk about health care, we'd talk about the minimum wage. [chuckles softly] He didn't have a sore throat.
No.
You kept him off the board so he could come back on and fix it.
Yeah.
When are you going to announce?
Announce what?
That he's running for President.
I'm pretty sure we just did. Toby exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Charlie are watching C.J. on Mrs. Landingham's T.V.

Dialogues.Line: Good morning. I'm going to read a short statement in response to the rather bizarre take on what was otherwise an unremarkable...
I think the whole damn thing is bizarre. They walk into THE OVAL OFFICE.
Mr. President, I don't know if this is the right moment...
The right moment for what?

Donna Moss needs a favor. While talking last night to Karen Cahill, she accidentally dropped her underwear. She feels that there's a chance Karen Cahill may have misinterpreted that and Donna asked me to ask you if you would call Karen Cahill and make it clear she wasn't making a sexual advance.
Well, I'm not sure there is a right moment for you to ask me that, Charlie.
So I should tell her no?
Yeah.
[enters] Good evening, Mr. President
Donna wants me to call Karen Cahill and make it clear she wasn't hitting on her when she gave her her underwear.
Yeah, that's 'cause I made fun of her shoes and Sam said there were nuclear weapons in Kyrgyzstan and Donna went to clear up the mix up and accidentally left her underwear.
There can't possibly be nuclear weapons in Kyrgyzstan.
Mr. President, please don't wade hip deep into this story.
Sir?
Okay. Yeah.
Toby.
[shaking his head] I'm going to bed. If anybody thinks of new ways for us to make friends don't hesitate to wake me. Or, you know, just feel free to start a fire.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Good night. Bartlet exits along the outside corridor, passes all the windows, which Toby can see. Charlie exits the Oval Office.
Toby. Toby enters the Oval Office.
He didn't want to see me.
He'll be all right in the morning.
Yeah.
You're the Communications Director. It was a TV show.
It was a blunder from top to bottom. You should know it could have been avoided at several points along the way if I'd listened to C.J.
Or me.
Yeah.
Alexander Hamilton didn't think we should have political parties. Neither did John Adams. He thought political parties led to divisiveness.
They do. They should. We have honest disagreements. Arguments are good.
Only if they lead to statesmanship. Or it's just theatre. And statesmanship is compromise.
What about persuasion? They're coming for us, Leo.
I know.
I mean they're coming for us now.
Toby, if you knew what it was like getting him to run the first time...
I know.
Like pushing molasses up a sandy hill. If I go and tell him it's time to run again he's going to get crazy... and frustrated. He's going to sink into his head and he's going to say he's not running.
Yeah.
Yeah.
So we've got to do it for him. We'll keep it away from this office but we've got to get real now. Leo, Ann Stark's a war time consigliere. That's why she was bumped up.
I'm a wartime consigliere too, Toby. I was just hoping it'd be peace time a little longer.
Yeah.
Son of a bitch!
Yeah.
Shake my hand. Toby does.
We just formed it.
Formed what?
The Committee to Reelect the President.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
